docs.title: BlogMore
docs.text:
Warning

BlogMore is an expeirment in using GitHub Copilot to develop a whole project form start to finish. As such, almost every part of this documentation was generated by Copilot and what it knows about the project. Please keep this in mind.

From what I can see at the moment the documentation is broadly correct, and I will update and correct it as I work through it and check it myself. Of course, I will welcome reports of problems or fixes.

BlogMore is a blog-oriented static site generation engine built in Python. It transforms your Markdown files into a complete, modern blog website with a clean, responsive design.

docs.title: What is BlogMore?
docs.text: BlogMore focuses on simplicity and efficiency in creating blog-focused websites. Write your posts in Markdown with frontmatter metadata, and BlogMore handles the rest—generating a complete static site with post listings, tag pages, category pages, archives, and RSS/Atom feeds.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Markdown-based content - Write all your posts in Markdown with support for code highlighting, tables, footnotes, and GitHub-style admonitions
  • Frontmatter metadata - Control all post metadata (title, date, tags, category, author) through YAML frontmatter
  • Responsive design - Clean, modern interface that works beautifully on mobile, tablet, and desktop
  • Jinja2 templating - Fully customisable templates for complete control over your site's appearance
  • Automatic organisation - Generates tag pages, category pages, and chronological archives automatically
  • RSS and Atom feeds - Built-in feed generation for syndication
  • Live preview server - Local development server with automatic rebuilding on changes
  • GitHub Pages integration - Simple publishing workflow to GitHub Pages (or any git branch)
  • Configurable - Extensive configuration options via YAML config files or command-line arguments
  • Sidebar customisation - Optional logo, custom links, and social media icons
  • SEO optimisation - Proper meta tags, Open Graph tags, and Twitter Card support
  • Automatic icon generation - Generate favicons and platform-specific icons (iOS, Android, Windows) from a single source image
  • Client-side search - Optional full-text search across post titles and content, running entirely in the browser with no external services (enable with --with-search)

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: BlogMore requires Python 3.12 or later.

docs.title: Using uv (recommended)
docs.text:
The fastest and most modern way to install BlogMore is with uv:

uv tool install blogmore

docs.title: Using pipx
docs.text:
You can also install BlogMore using pipx:

pipx install blogmore

docs.title: From source
docs.text:
To install from source for development:

git clone https://github.com/davep/blogmore.git
cd blogmore
uv sync

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Once installed, creating a blog is straightforward:

Create a directory for your posts:

mkdir posts

Write your first post in posts/hello.md:

---
title: Hello World
date: 2024-01-15
tags: [welcome, meta]
---

Welcome to my new blog powered by BlogMore!

Generate your site:

blogmore build posts/

Preview locally:

blogmore serve posts/

Visit http://localhost:8000 to see your site.

For a comprehensive walkthrough, see the Getting Started guide.

docs.title: Command Line Reference
docs.text: This guide documents all BlogMore command-line options and commands.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text: blogmore <command> [arguments] [options]

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
BlogMore provides three main commands:

  • build - Generate the static site
  • serve - Generate and serve the site locally with auto-reload
  • publish - Build and publish the site to a git branch

docs.title: Command Aliases
docs.text:
Several commands have aliases for convenience:

  • build, generate, gen - All equivalent
  • serve, test - Both start the development server

docs.title: --version
docs.text:
Display the BlogMore version and exit.

blogmore --version

docs.title: Build Command
docs.text: Generate a static site from Markdown posts.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
blogmore build <content_dir> [options]
blogmore generate <content_dir> [options]
blogmore gen <content_dir> [options]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
content_dir (optional if specified in config file) : Directory containing your Markdown blog posts. BlogMore scans this directory recursively for .md files.

blogmore build posts/

docs.title: -c, --config <path>
docs.text:
Path to a YAML configuration file. If not specified, BlogMore automatically searches for blogmore.yaml or blogmore.yml in the current directory (.yaml takes precedence).

blogmore build posts/ --config custom-config.yaml

docs.title: -t, --templates <path>
docs.text:
Directory containing custom Jinja2 templates. If not specified, uses the bundled default templates.

blogmore build posts/ --templates my-templates/

Custom templates should follow the structure of the default templates: - base.html - index.html - post.html - archive.html - tag.html - category.html - static/style.css

docs.title: -o, --output <path>
docs.text:
Output directory for the generated site. Default: output/

blogmore build posts/ --output public/

docs.title: --site-title <title>
docs.text:
Title of your blog site. Default: My Blog

blogmore build posts/ --site-title "Dave's Blog"

docs.title: --site-subtitle <subtitle>
docs.text:
Subtitle or tagline for your site. Optional.

blogmore build posts/ \
  --site-title "Dave's Blog" \
  --site-subtitle "Thoughts on Python and technology"

docs.title: --site-url <url>
docs.text:
Base URL of your site. Used for generating absolute URLs in RSS/Atom feeds and canonical URLs. Optional but recommended.

blogmore build posts/ --site-url "https://davep.org/blog"

docs.title: --include-drafts
docs.text:
Include posts marked with draft: true in frontmatter. By default, drafts are excluded.

blogmore build posts/ --include-drafts

docs.title: --clean-first
docs.text:
Remove the output directory before generating the site. Useful to ensure no stale files remain.

blogmore build posts/ --clean-first

docs.title: --posts-per-feed <number>
docs.text:
Maximum number of posts to include in RSS and Atom feeds. Default: 20

blogmore build posts/ --posts-per-feed 50

docs.title: --default-author <name>
docs.text:
Default author name for posts that don't specify an author field in frontmatter.

blogmore build posts/ --default-author "Dave Pearson"

docs.title: --extra-stylesheet <url>
docs.text:
URL of an additional stylesheet to include. Can be an absolute URL or a path relative to your site root. This option can be used multiple times to include multiple stylesheets.

blogmore build posts/ \
  --extra-stylesheet "https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter" \
  --extra-stylesheet "/assets/custom.css"

docs.title: --icon-source <filename>
docs.text:
Filename of the source icon image in the extras/ directory. BlogMore will generate favicons and platform-specific icons from this image.

blogmore build posts/ --icon-source "my-logo.png"

If not specified, BlogMore auto-detects common icon filenames: icon.png, icon.jpg, source-icon.png, app-icon.png.

When a source icon is provided or detected, BlogMore generates 18 optimised icon files for iOS, Android, Windows, and standard favicons.

See Using BlogMore - Adding Site Icons for detailed usage.

docs.title: --with-search
docs.text:
Enable client-side full-text search. When set, BlogMore generates a search_index.json file containing every post's title, URL, date, and plain-text content, and a /search.html page that performs in-browser search as the reader types. A Search link is also added to the navigation bar. No external services are required.

Search is disabled by default. Pass this flag to opt in.

blogmore build posts/ --with-search

When search is later disabled (flag omitted), any stale search.html, search_index.json, and search.js files from a previous build are automatically removed.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Basic site generation: 

blogmore build posts/

Generate with custom options: 

blogmore build posts/ \
  --output public/ \
  --site-title "My Tech Blog" \
  --site-url "https://example.com" \
  --default-author "Jane Smith"

Clean build with drafts included: 

blogmore build posts/ --clean-first --include-drafts

docs.title: Serve Command
docs.text: Start a local development server that watches for changes and automatically rebuilds your site.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text:
blogmore serve [content_dir] [options]
blogmore test [content_dir] [options]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
content_dir (optional) : Directory containing Markdown posts. If provided, BlogMore will generate the site before serving. If omitted, serves an existing site from the output directory without regeneration.

# Generate and serve with auto-rebuild
blogmore serve posts/

# Serve an existing site without generation
blogmore serve

docs.title: -p, --port <number>
docs.text:
Port number for the local server. Default: 8000

blogmore serve posts/ --port 3000

docs.title: --no-watch
docs.text:
Disable watching for file changes. The site will be generated once (if content_dir is provided) but won't automatically rebuild on changes.

blogmore serve posts/ --no-watch

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: The serve command also accepts all the build command options: - -c, --config - -t, --templates - -o, --output - --site-title - --site-subtitle - --site-url - --include-drafts - --clean-first - --posts-per-feed - --default-author - --extra-stylesheet - --icon-source - --with-search

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Basic development server: 

blogmore serve posts/

Custom port with drafts: 

blogmore serve posts/ --port 3000 --include-drafts

Serve existing site without watching: 

blogmore serve --output public/ --no-watch

Full configuration: 

blogmore serve posts/ \
  --port 8080 \
  --output build/ \
  --site-title "Dev Blog" \
  --include-drafts

docs.title: Publish Command
docs.text: Build your site and publish it to a git branch, typically for GitHub Pages.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: blogmore publish <content_dir> [options]

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• You must be in a git repository
  • Git must be installed and available in your PATH
  • You should have a remote repository configured

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
content_dir (optional if specified in config file) : Directory containing your Markdown blog posts.

blogmore publish posts/

docs.title: --branch <branch-name>
docs.text:
Git branch to publish to. Default: gh-pages

blogmore publish posts/ --branch main

docs.title: --remote <remote-name>
docs.text:
Git remote to push to. Default: origin

blogmore publish posts/ --remote upstream

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text: The publish command also accepts all the build command options: - -c, --config - -t, --templates - -o, --output - --site-title - --site-subtitle - --site-url - --include-drafts - --clean-first - --posts-per-feed - --default-author - --extra-stylesheet - --icon-source - --with-search

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
When you run publish, BlogMore:

  1. Builds your site using the build command options
  2. Verifies you're in a git repository
  3. Creates a git worktree for the target branch in a temporary directory
  4. Creates the branch if it doesn't exist
  5. Clears the branch and copies your built site into it
  6. Creates a .nojekyll file (required for GitHub Pages)
  7. Commits the changes with a timestamp
  8. Pushes to the specified remote

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Publish to GitHub Pages: 

blogmore publish posts/ --branch gh-pages

Publish with custom configuration: 

blogmore publish posts/ \
  --branch main \
  --site-url "https://example.com" \
  --clean-first

Publish to a different remote: 

blogmore publish posts/ --remote upstream --branch pages

docs.title: Configuration File Priority
docs.text:
When both a configuration file and command-line options are present, command-line options always take precedence.

Example: 

# blogmore.yaml
site_title: "Config Title"


# Command-line overrides config file
blogmore build posts/ --site-title "CLI Title"
# Result: site_title will be "CLI Title"

docs.title: Path Expansion
docs.text:
All path arguments support tilde (~) expansion for home directory:

blogmore build ~/blog/posts/ --output ~/public_html/blog/

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text:
BlogMore uses standard exit codes:

  • 0 - Success
  • 1 - Error (with message printed to stderr)

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: BlogMore does not currently use environment variables for configuration. All configuration is done through command-line arguments or configuration files.

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
Display help for BlogMore: 

blogmore --help

Display help for a specific command: 

blogmore build --help
blogmore serve --help
blogmore publish --help

docs.title: Daily Writing Workflow
docs.text:
# Start development server
blogmore serve posts/ --include-drafts

# Write and edit posts...
# Browser automatically refreshes on save

# When ready to publish
blogmore publish posts/

docs.title: Using Configuration Files
docs.text:
Create blogmore.yaml: 

content_dir: posts
output: public
site_title: "My Blog"
site_url: "https://example.com"
default_author: "Your Name"

Then use simplified commands: 

blogmore build
blogmore serve
blogmore publish

docs.title: Multiple Sites
docs.text:
Use different config files for different sites: 

blogmore build --config personal-blog.yaml
blogmore build --config work-blog.yaml

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Configuration - Detailed configuration file documentation
  • Getting Started - Tutorial for creating your first blog

docs.title: Configuration File Reference
docs.text: This guide documents all configuration options available in BlogMore configuration files.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: BlogMore supports YAML configuration files to avoid repetitive command-line arguments. Configuration files make it easier to manage complex setups and maintain consistent settings across multiple commands.

docs.title: Configuration File Discovery
docs.text:
BlogMore automatically searches for configuration files in the current directory:

  1. blogmore.yaml (checked first)
  2. blogmore.yml (checked second)

If both exist, blogmore.yaml takes precedence.

docs.title: Specifying a Configuration File
docs.text:
Use the -c or --config option to specify a custom configuration file:

blogmore build --config my-config.yaml

docs.title: Configuration Priority
docs.text:
When both a configuration file and command-line options are present, command-line options always take precedence. This allows you to override specific settings without modifying the configuration file.

Example: 

# blogmore.yaml
site_title: "My Blog"
output: output


# Override site_title but keep output from config
blogmore build --site-title "Different Title"

docs.title: Minimal Configuration
docs.text:
At minimum, you typically want to specify the content directory:

content_dir: posts

docs.title: Recommended Configuration
docs.text:
A more complete basic configuration:

content_dir: posts
output: public
site_title: "My Blog"
site_subtitle: "Thoughts on code and technology"
site_url: "https://example.com"
default_author: "Your Name"

docs.title: content_dir
docs.text:
Directory containing your Markdown blog posts. BlogMore scans this directory recursively for .md files.

Type: String (path) Default: None (required for build and publish, optional for serve)

content_dir: posts

# Can use relative or absolute paths
content_dir: /home/user/blog/posts

docs.title: output
docs.text:
Directory where the generated static site will be created.

Type: String (path) Default: output

output: public

# Use a different output directory
output: build/site

docs.title: templates
docs.text:
Directory containing custom Jinja2 templates. If not specified, uses BlogMore's bundled default templates.

Type: String (path) Default: None (uses bundled templates)

templates: my-templates

Custom templates should include: - base.html - Base template - index.html - Homepage listing - post.html - Individual post page - archive.html - Archive page - tag.html - Tag listing page - category.html - Category listing page - static/style.css - Stylesheet

docs.title: site_title
docs.text:
The title of your blog, displayed in the header and browser title bar.

Type: String Default: My Blog

site_title: "Dave's Tech Blog"

docs.title: site_subtitle
docs.text:
An optional subtitle or tagline displayed below the site title.

Type: String Default: Empty string

site_subtitle: "Python, web development, and open source"

docs.title: site_url
docs.text:
The base URL of your site. Used for generating absolute URLs in RSS/Atom feeds, canonical URLs, and Open Graph tags.

Type: String (URL) Default: Empty string

site_url: "https://davep.org/blog"

Important: Include the protocol (https://) but no trailing slash.

docs.title: include_drafts
docs.text:
Include posts marked with draft: true in frontmatter. Useful during development.

Type: Boolean Default: false

include_drafts: false

# Include drafts for local testing
include_drafts: true

docs.title: clean_first
docs.text:
Remove the output directory before generating the site. Ensures no stale files remain from previous builds.

Type: Boolean Default: false

clean_first: true

docs.title: posts_per_feed
docs.text:
Maximum number of posts to include in RSS and Atom feeds.

Type: Integer Default: 20

posts_per_feed: 30

# Include more posts in feeds
posts_per_feed: 50

docs.title: default_author
docs.text:
Default author name used for posts that don't specify an author field in frontmatter.

Type: String Default: None

default_author: "Dave Pearson"

docs.title: icon_source
docs.text:
Filename of the source icon image in the extras/ directory. BlogMore will generate favicons and platform-specific icons from this image.

Type: String Default: None (auto-detects icon.png, icon.jpg, source-icon.png, app-icon.png)

icon_source: "icon.png"

# Use a custom filename
icon_source: "my-logo.png"

When a source icon is provided or detected, BlogMore generates 18 icon files optimised for:

  • iOS (Apple Touch Icons)
  • Android/Chrome (with PWA manifest)
  • Windows/Edge (with tile configuration)
  • Standard favicons (multi-resolution)

Requirements:

  • Format: PNG or JPEG
  • Size: Square image, ideally 1024×1024 or larger
  • Location: Must be in the extras/ subdirectory of your content directory

See Using BlogMore - Adding Site Icons for detailed usage instructions.

docs.title: with_search
docs.text:
Enable client-side full-text search. When true, BlogMore generates a search_index.json file containing every post's title, URL, date, and plain-text content, and a /search.html page that performs in-browser search as the reader types. A Search link is also added to the navigation bar. No external services are required.

Type: Boolean Default: false

with_search: true

When set back to false (or omitted), any stale search.html, search_index.json, and search.js files from a previous build that had search enabled are automatically removed.

docs.title: extra_stylesheets
docs.text:
List of additional stylesheets to include. Can be absolute URLs or paths relative to your site root.

Type: List of strings (URLs or paths) Default: None

extra_stylesheets:
  - https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter
  - /assets/custom.css
  - /assets/syntax-highlighting.css

Note: Stylesheets are included in the order specified.

docs.title: site_logo
docs.text:
Path or URL to a logo image displayed in the sidebar.

Type: String (URL or path) Default: None

site_logo: /images/logo.png

# Can use external URLs
site_logo: https://example.com/images/logo.svg

docs.title: links
docs.text:
Custom links displayed in the sidebar. Each link has a title and url.

Type: List of objects with title and url fields Default: None

links:
  - title: About
    url: /about.html
  - title: Projects
    url: /projects.html
  - title: Contact
    url: /contact.html

# Can link to external sites
links:
  - title: Main Website
    url: https://example.com
  - title: GitHub
    url: https://github.com/username

docs.title: socials
docs.text:
Social media links displayed in the sidebar as icons. Each entry has a site (the social media platform) and url.

Type: List of objects with site and url fields Default: None

socials:
  - site: github
    url: https://github.com/davep
  - site: mastodon
    url: https://fosstodon.org/@davep
  - site: twitter
    url: https://twitter.com/username

Supported platforms: Any Font Awesome brand icon name works (e.g., github, mastodon, twitter, linkedin, youtube, facebook, instagram, bluesky, threads, lastfm, steam, etc.).

docs.title: Serve Command Options
docs.text: Options specific to the serve command. These are only used when running blogmore serve.

docs.title: port
docs.text:
Port number for the local development server.

Type: Integer Default: 8000

port: 3000

docs.title: no_watch
docs.text:
Disable watching for file changes. The site will be generated once but won't automatically rebuild.

Type: Boolean Default: false

no_watch: false

# Disable auto-rebuild
no_watch: true

docs.title: Publish Command Options
docs.text: Options specific to the publish command. These are only used when running blogmore publish.

docs.title: branch
docs.text:
Git branch to publish to.

Type: String Default: gh-pages

branch: gh-pages

# Publish to main branch instead
branch: main

docs.title: remote
docs.text:
Git remote to push to.

Type: String Default: origin

remote: origin

# Push to a different remote
remote: upstream

docs.title: Complete Example Configuration
docs.text:
Here's a comprehensive example showing all available options:

# Core settings
content_dir: posts
output: public
templates: custom-templates

# Site metadata
site_title: "Dave's Tech Blog"
site_subtitle: "Python, web development, and open source"
site_url: "https://davep.org/blog"

# Content options
include_drafts: false
clean_first: true
posts_per_feed: 30
default_author: "Dave Pearson"
icon_source: "icon.png"
with_search: true

# Styling
extra_stylesheets:
  - https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter:wght@400;600;700
  - /assets/custom.css

# Sidebar configuration
site_logo: /images/logo.png

links:
  - title: About
    url: /about.html
  - title: Projects
    url: /projects.html
  - title: Contact
    url: /contact.html

socials:
  - site: github
    url: https://github.com/davep
  - site: mastodon
    url: https://fosstodon.org/@davep
  - site: lastfm
    url: https://www.last.fm/user/davep

# Serve options
port: 8080
no_watch: false

# Publish options
branch: gh-pages
remote: origin

docs.title: Configuration Profiles
docs.text: You can maintain multiple configuration files for different purposes:

docs.title: Development Configuration
docs.text:
blogmore-dev.yaml: 

content_dir: posts
output: dev-output
site_title: "My Blog [DEV]"
site_url: "http://localhost:8000"
include_drafts: true
port: 8000

Usage: 

blogmore serve --config blogmore-dev.yaml

docs.title: Production Configuration
docs.text:
blogmore-prod.yaml: 

content_dir: posts
output: public
site_title: "My Blog"
site_url: "https://example.com"
include_drafts: false
clean_first: true
branch: gh-pages

Usage: 

blogmore publish --config blogmore-prod.yaml

docs.title: Keep Configuration in Version Control
docs.text:
Commit your blogmore.yaml to version control so team members or future you can easily build the site with the same settings.

git add blogmore.yaml
git commit -m "Add BlogMore configuration"

docs.title: Use Comments
docs.text:
YAML supports comments. Use them to document your configuration choices:

# Use a custom port to avoid conflicts with other local servers
port: 3000

# Include more posts in feeds since we publish frequently
posts_per_feed: 50

docs.title: Test Configuration Changes Locally
docs.text:
Always test configuration changes with blogmore serve before publishing:

# Test locally first
blogmore serve --config new-config.yaml

# If everything looks good, publish
blogmore publish --config new-config.yaml

docs.title: Override for Testing
docs.text:
Use command-line overrides to test variations without modifying your config file:

# Test with drafts without changing config
blogmore serve --include-drafts

# Test different site title
blogmore build --site-title "Test Title"

docs.title: Validation
docs.text:
BlogMore validates configuration files on load and will report errors if:

  • Required fields are missing (when running build or publish)
  • File paths don't exist
  • Invalid values are provided (e.g., non-integer for port)

Error messages include the specific problem and the configuration file location.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Command Line Reference - All command-line options
  • Getting Started - Tutorial with configuration examples

docs.title: Getting Started with BlogMore
docs.text: This guide will walk you through creating your first blog with BlogMore, from initial setup to publishing your site.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Ensure you have BlogMore installed. If not, see the installation instructions.

docs.title: 1. Create Your Content Directory
docs.text:
First, create a directory to hold your blog posts:

mkdir posts
cd posts

You can name this directory anything you like—posts, content, blog, etc. BlogMore will scan it recursively for Markdown files.

docs.title: 2. Understanding Directory Structure
docs.text:
BlogMore is flexible about how you organise your posts. Here are some common patterns:

Flat structure (all posts in one directory): 

posts/
  ├── hello-world.md
  ├── python-tips.md
  └── web-development.md

Note: Files can be date-prefixed (e.g., 2026-02-18-hello-world.md) and BlogMore will automatically remove the date prefix from the URL slug. The post will still use the date field from frontmatter for chronological ordering.

Organised by date: 

posts/
  ├── 2024/
  │   ├── 01/
  │   │   └── hello-world.md
  │   └── 02/
  │       └── python-tips.md
  └── 2025/
      └── 01/
          └── web-development.md

Organised by topic: 

posts/
  ├── python/
  │   ├── decorators.md
  │   └── type-hints.md
  └── web/
      ├── css-grid.md
      └── javascript-tips.md

All approaches work equally well—BlogMore determines post order by the date field in frontmatter, not by directory structure.

docs.title: Writing Your First Post
docs.text:
Create a new file posts/hello-world.md:

---
title: Hello World
date: 2024-01-15
tags: [welcome, blogging]
category: meta
author: Your Name
---

Welcome to my new blog! This is my first post using BlogMore.

## Why I Started This Blog

I wanted a simple, fast, and customisable blogging platform...

## What to Expect

I'll be writing about:

- Python programming
- Web development
- Software engineering practices

Stay tuned for more content!

docs.title: Understanding Frontmatter
docs.text: Frontmatter is the YAML section at the top of your Markdown file, enclosed by --- markers. It contains metadata about your post.

docs.title: Required Fields
docs.text: • title - The post title (must be present)

docs.title: Common Optional Fields
docs.text:
• date - Publication date in YYYY-MM-DD format (posts without dates appear at the end)
  • tags - List of tags (as a YAML list or comma-separated string)
  • category - A single category for the post
  • author - Post author name
  • draft - Set to true to mark as a draft (excluded by default)
  • description - Brief description (used for meta tags; falls back to first paragraph)

docs.title: SEO and Social Media Fields
docs.text:
• cover - Cover image URL or path for social media sharing
  • twitter_creator - Author's Twitter handle (e.g., @username)
  • twitter_site - Site's Twitter handle
  • modified - Last modification date

docs.title: Date Formats
docs.text:
BlogMore accepts several date formats:

date: 2024-01-15              # Simple date
date: 2024-01-15 14:30:00     # With time
date: 2024-01-15T14:30:00Z    # ISO format with timezone

docs.title: Tags Examples
docs.text:
Tags can be written as a YAML list or comma-separated string:

# YAML list (recommended)
tags: [python, web, tutorial]

# Comma-separated string
tags: python, web, tutorial

# YAML list (multi-line)
tags:
  - python
  - web
  - tutorial

docs.title: Markdown Features
docs.text: BlogMore supports standard Markdown plus several extensions.

docs.title: Code Blocks with Syntax Highlighting
docs.text:
Use fenced code blocks with language specifiers:

```python
def hello():
    print("Hello, world!")
```

docs.title: Tables
docs.text:
| Feature | Supported |
|---------|-----------|
| Tables  | Yes       |
| Code    | Yes       |

docs.title: Footnotes
docs.text:
Here's a statement with a footnote[^1].

[^1]: This is the footnote content.

docs.title: GitHub-Style Admonitions
docs.text:
BlogMore supports GitHub-style alert boxes:

> [!NOTE]
> Useful information that users should know.

> [!TIP]
> Helpful advice for doing things better.

> [!IMPORTANT]
> Key information users need to know.

> [!WARNING]
> Urgent information needing attention.

> [!CAUTION]
> Advice about risks or negative outcomes.

Each admonition type has its own colour and icon.

docs.title: Building Your Site
docs.text:
Once you've written some posts, generate your site:

blogmore build posts/

This creates an output/ directory containing your complete static site. You can customise the output directory with the -o flag:

blogmore build posts/ -o my-site/

docs.title: Local Testing with the Development Server
docs.text:
The serve command starts a local HTTP server and automatically rebuilds your site when files change:

blogmore serve posts/

This will: 1. Build your site to output/ 2. Start a server on http://localhost:8000 3. Watch for changes and automatically rebuild

Open http://localhost:8000 in your browser to preview your site.

docs.title: Serve Options
docs.text:
# Use a different port
blogmore serve posts/ --port 3000

# Specify output directory
blogmore serve posts/ -o my-site/

# Disable auto-rebuild on changes
blogmore serve posts/ --no-watch

# Serve an existing site without rebuilding
blogmore serve -o output/

docs.title: Categories vs Tags
docs.text:
Understanding the difference helps you organise content effectively:

  • Categories - Broad topics or sections of your blog. Each post has zero or one category. Example: python, javascript, devops
  • Tags - Specific topics that can apply across categories. Posts can have multiple tags. Example: tutorial, beginner, advanced, testing

Example: 

---
title: Python Decorators Tutorial
category: python
tags: [tutorial, beginner, decorators]
---

Visitors can view all posts in a category at /category/python.html or all posts with a tag at /tag/tutorial.html.

docs.title: Working with Drafts
docs.text:
Mark posts as drafts while you're still working on them:

---
title: Work in Progress
date: 2024-01-20
draft: true
---

Drafts are excluded by default. Include them during development:

blogmore serve posts/ --include-drafts

docs.title: Publishing to GitHub Pages
docs.text: Once your site is ready, publish it to GitHub Pages using the publish command.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. Your blog must be in a git repository
  2. You must have a GitHub repository set up
  3. Git must be installed and configured

docs.title: Publishing Steps
docs.text:
Ensure your changes are committed:

git add .
git commit -m "Add new blog posts"

Publish to GitHub Pages:

blogmore publish posts/ --branch gh-pages --remote origin

This command will: - Build your site - Create or update the gh-pages branch - Copy the generated site to that branch - Commit and push the changes

docs.title: Configuring GitHub Pages
docs.text:
After your first publish, configure GitHub Pages in your repository:

  1. Go to your repository on GitHub
  2. Click Settings → Pages
  3. Under "Source", select the gh-pages branch
  4. Click Save

Your site will be available at https://username.github.io/repository-name/ within a few minutes.

For more information, see the GitHub Pages documentation.

docs.title: Publishing to Other Branches
docs.text:
You can publish to any branch:

blogmore publish posts/ --branch main --remote origin

docs.title: Configuration Files
docs.text:
For projects with many options, create a blogmore.yaml configuration file:

content_dir: posts
output: output
site_title: "My Blog"
site_subtitle: "Thoughts on code and life"
site_url: "https://username.github.io/blog"
default_author: "Your Name"
posts_per_feed: 30

Then simply run:

blogmore build
blogmore serve
blogmore publish

See the Configuration guide for all available options.

docs.title: Site Metadata
docs.text:
Set your site's title, subtitle, and URL via command-line or config file:

blogmore build posts/ \
  --site-title "My Blog" \
  --site-subtitle "Thoughts on Technology" \
  --site-url "https://example.com"

docs.title: Adding a Sidebar Logo and Links
docs.text:
Create a blogmore.yaml with sidebar configuration:

site_logo: /images/logo.png

links:
  - title: About
    url: /about.html
  - title: Projects
    url: /projects.html

socials:
  - site: github
    url: https://github.com/username
  - site: mastodon
    url: https://fosstodon.org/@username

docs.title: Custom Stylesheets
docs.text:
Add your own CSS to override or extend the default styles:

extra_stylesheets:
  - https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter
  - /assets/custom.css

docs.title: Custom Templates
docs.text:
For complete control, copy the default templates and modify them:

# Copy default templates (from the BlogMore installation)
mkdir my-templates
# Copy from src/blogmore/templates/ in the BlogMore source

# Use your templates
blogmore build posts/ --templates my-templates/

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you have a working blog, explore these topics:

  • Command Line Reference - All available commands and options
  • Configuration Guide - Detailed configuration file documentation
  • Customise templates to match your personal style
  • Add custom CSS for typography and colours
  • Set up automated publishing with GitHub Actions

Happy blogging!

docs.title: Using BlogMore
docs.text: This guide covers the day-to-day use of BlogMore after initial setup.

docs.title: Creating a New Post
docs.text:
Create a new Markdown file in your content directory with frontmatter:

---
title: My New Post
date: 2024-01-20
tags: [python, tutorial]
category: programming
---

Your post content goes here...

docs.title: Post Metadata
docs.text:
Every post requires a title field. Other common fields include:

  • date - Publication date (YYYY-MM-DD format)
  • tags - List of tags for categorisation
  • category - A single category
  • author - Post author name
  • draft - Mark as draft (excluded by default)

See Getting Started for complete frontmatter documentation.

docs.title: Starting the Development Server
docs.text:
Start a local server that automatically rebuilds on changes:

blogmore serve posts/

Visit http://localhost:8000 to preview your site. The site automatically rebuilds when you save changes to any Markdown file.

docs.title: Including Drafts
docs.text:
Work on unpublished posts by marking them as drafts and including them during development:

---
title: Work in Progress
draft: true
---

blogmore serve posts/ --include-drafts

docs.title: Using Different Ports
docs.text:
If port 8000 is in use, specify a different port:

blogmore serve posts/ --port 3000

docs.title: Building Your Site
docs.text:
Generate a production-ready static site:

blogmore build posts/

This creates an output/ directory with your complete site. You can then deploy this directory to any static hosting service.

docs.title: Clean Builds
docs.text:
Remove the output directory before building to ensure no stale files:

blogmore build posts/ --clean-first

docs.title: Publishing to GitHub Pages
docs.text:
Publish your site directly to GitHub Pages:

blogmore publish posts/

This builds your site and pushes it to the gh-pages branch. See Getting Started - Publishing to GitHub Pages for setup instructions.

docs.title: Publishing to Other Branches
docs.text:
Publish to any git branch:

blogmore publish posts/ --branch main

docs.title: Using Categories
docs.text:
Categories help organise posts into distinct sections:

---
title: Python Decorators Explained
category: python
---

Visitors can view all posts in a category at /category/python.html.

docs.title: Using Tags
docs.text:
Tags allow cross-categorisation:

---
title: Python Decorators Explained
category: python
tags: [tutorial, intermediate, decorators]
---

Tags appear on post pages and visitors can view all posts with a tag at /tag/tutorial.html.

docs.title: Using Configuration Files
docs.text:
Create a blogmore.yaml to avoid repeating command-line options:

content_dir: posts
site_title: "My Blog"
site_url: "https://example.com"
default_author: "Your Name"

Then use simplified commands:

blogmore build
blogmore serve
blogmore publish

See the Configuration Guide for all options.

docs.title: Adding Custom Styles
docs.text:
Include additional stylesheets:

extra_stylesheets:
  - https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter
  - /assets/custom.css

Place custom.css in your content directory at assets/custom.css and BlogMore will copy it to the output.

docs.title: Adding Site Icons
docs.text: BlogMore can automatically generate favicons and platform-specific icons from a single source image. This creates icons optimised for iOS, Android, Windows, and all modern browsers.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Place a square, high-resolution image (ideally 1024×1024 or larger) in your content directory's extras/ subdirectory:

posts/
  ├── extras/
  │   └── icon.png
  └── my-first-post.md

BlogMore will automatically detect the icon and generate 18 icon files:

  • Favicon files - Multi-resolution .ico and PNG alternatives (16×16, 32×32, 96×96)
  • Apple Touch Icons - Optimised for iOS devices (120×120, 152×152, 167×167, 180×180)
  • Android/Chrome icons - PWA-ready with web manifest (192×192, 512×512)
  • Windows tiles - Microsoft Edge and Windows 10+ tiles (70×70, 144×144, 150×150, 310×310, 310×150)

All generated icons are placed in the /icons subdirectory of your output.

docs.title: Using a Custom Icon Filename
docs.text:
If your icon has a different filename, specify it in your configuration:

icon_source: "my-logo.png"

Or via command line:

blogmore build posts/ --icon-source my-logo.png

docs.title: Supported Source Filenames
docs.text:
BlogMore auto-detects these filenames in the extras/ directory:

  • icon.png (recommended)
  • icon.jpg or icon.jpeg
  • source-icon.png
  • app-icon.png

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Format: PNG or JPEG
  • Size: 1024×1024 or larger (square)
  • Transparency: PNG with transparent backgrounds works best

docs.title: What Gets Generated
docs.text:
When a source icon is detected, BlogMore generates:

output/
  └── icons/
      ├── favicon.ico               (16×16, 32×32, 48×48 multi-res)
      ├── favicon-16x16.png
      ├── favicon-32x32.png
      ├── favicon-96x96.png
      ├── apple-touch-icon.png      (180×180)
      ├── apple-touch-icon-120.png  (120×120)
      ├── apple-touch-icon-152.png  (152×152)
      ├── apple-touch-icon-167.png  (167×167)
      ├── apple-touch-icon-precomposed.png
      ├── android-chrome-192x192.png
      ├── android-chrome-512x512.png
      ├── mstile-70x70.png
      ├── mstile-144x144.png
      ├── mstile-150x150.png
      ├── mstile-310x310.png
      ├── mstile-310x150.png
      ├── site.webmanifest          (PWA manifest)
      └── browserconfig.xml         (Windows tile config)

The necessary HTML meta tags are automatically added to all pages, but only when the icons exist.

docs.title: Customising the Sidebar
docs.text:
Add a logo, custom links, and social media icons:

site_logo: /images/logo.png

links:
  - title: About
    url: /about.html
  - title: Projects
    url: /projects.html

socials:
  - site: github
    url: https://github.com/username
  - site: mastodon
    url: https://fosstodon.org/@username

docs.title: Markdown Features
docs.text: BlogMore supports standard Markdown plus several extensions.

docs.title: Syntax Highlighting
docs.text:
Use fenced code blocks with language specifiers:

```python
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"
```

docs.title: Tables
docs.text:
| Feature | Status |
|---------|--------|
| Tables  | ✓      |
| Code    | ✓      |

docs.title: Admonitions
docs.text:
Create alert boxes for important information:

> [!NOTE]
> This is a note with useful information.

> [!WARNING]
> This is a warning about something important.

Available types: NOTE, TIP, IMPORTANT, WARNING, CAUTION

docs.title: Footnotes
docs.text:
Add footnotes to your posts:

This statement needs a citation[^1].

[^1]: Source: Example Reference

docs.title: Changing Site Title
docs.text:
Update via configuration file or command line:

blogmore build posts/ --site-title "New Title"

docs.title: Setting Site URL
docs.text:
Important for RSS feeds and canonical URLs:

blogmore build posts/ --site-url "https://example.com"

docs.title: Controlling Feed Length
docs.text:
Limit the number of posts in RSS/Atom feeds:

blogmore build posts/ --posts-per-feed 30

docs.title: Using Custom Templates
docs.text:
Copy the default templates, customise them, and use them:

blogmore build posts/ --templates my-templates/

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
If port 8000 is already in use:

blogmore serve posts/ --port 8080

docs.title: Site Not Updating
docs.text:
Use clean builds to remove stale files:

blogmore build posts/ --clean-first

docs.title: Drafts Appearing in Production
docs.text:
Ensure include_drafts is not set in your production configuration:

# blogmore.yaml
include_drafts: false
